Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Public School Selection Processes, Educational Inequality, and the Meaning of Rejection.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1303603
PI: Annette Lareau
Co-PI: Shani Adia Evans
University of Pennsylvania

Each year, thousands of students apply to selective urban public high schools. Applicants can be selected or rejected by selective schools. The outcome of the selection process determines students' location within a stratified system of urban public schools. Students who are not admitted to a selective school attend typically under-resourced neighborhood high schools. This study investigates the significance of rejection for students who view school as a means to achieve upward mobility. The research questions motivating the study are: (1) How do students interpret the significance of the selection/rejection process for their own future? and (2) How, if at all, does the outcome of the selection process influence students' subsequent academic outlook. The study uses qualitative methods, including observation and interviewing.

The rejection experience has been largely absent from research on educational inequality. However, preliminary research suggests that rejected students interpret the negative outcome of the selection/rejection process as a marker of their diminished educational opportunity. Moreover, tentative evidence indicates that students who fail to access their preferred school become pessimistic about their educational future.

Broader Impacts
Increasingly, American public school students have the option to apply to schools other than their assigned neighborhood school. However, it is not simply that families choose schools. Schools also choose students. Thus, with increased options comes the possibility of rejection. This study offers the rejection experience as an important variable of interest in sociological studies of education. The significance of rejection for young students also has policy implications. This research could help focus attention on how and when selection should occur in U.S. public schools. By drawing attention to the effects of selection and school choice for those who do not attend their preferred schools, this study invites policy makers to take a closer look at the design and implementation of selection and school choice policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rejection and School Choice

            This study was designed to examine students’ experience with school choice and rejection from preferred schools. I conducted six months of fieldwork and interviewed fifteen 8th grade students at a public K-8 school in a large northeastern school district. In interviews, I asked students about their experience applying to selective admission public high schools. Later, I asked them about the experience of being admitted or rejected. My initial analysis indicated that the rejected students were unwilling to accept the outcome of the selection process. When students did not get into preferred schools, they nonetheless maintained hope that they would somehow “get in” before the school year started. Thus, I was unable to fully assess how students’ experienced rejection because students did not acknowledge that they had been rejected. I plan to conduct another round of data collection, involving parents to clarify findings and address remaining questions.

The High School Selection Process

            Simultaneously, I examined the admissions process at one academically selective high school. I wanted to learn how schools evaluated students for admission to selective high schools. I observed school staff as they reviewed admissions materials. I also observed twenty-two admissions interviews. I reviewed notes on applications and specific admissions decisions. In the admissions process, I found that the school staff paid great attention to students’ school behavioral records, as well as their attitude and personality. Rather than emphasizing academics alone, teachers were focused on admitting students that they wanted to encounter in the high school. The role of teacher preferences in the school choice processes is underexamined. Thus, I have a paper in which I argue that some teachers in schools of choice are motivated to select students that will provide a pleasant and rewarding work environment. I presented this paper at the American Sociological Association Annual Meeting 2014.

College Preparation and Choice

            While conducting fieldwork in the high school discussed above, I became interested in the preparation process at the school. After observing the stringent high school admissions process, I was surprised by how few top students went on to enroll at selective or elite colleges. I wanted to know what factors prevented students who had a long history of academic success and went to high performing high schools from enrolling in elite colleges. I interviewed fifty students and fourteen teachers at two selective high schools.  I find that the school-based adults who advised the students vigorously promoted “college for all,” but did not advocate elite college enrollment for high achieving students. Many of the teachers at the school were either unfamiliar with the higher education status hierarchy or dismissed its legitimacy
